ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A great survey of most/all of the major foreign policy events in America since 1900. I learned how to read about and analyze foreign policy decisions, and how to apply those lessons to current events.

This course provided me with a deeper understanding of important moments in American foreign policy and the forces that influence decision making. Focus on conceptional framework of interests, strategies, and tactics in formulating policy.
How to analyze negotiations, the difference between national interest, strategy, and tactic. How to judge foreign policy achievements or failures.

I learned a thorough history of all major turning points and involvements in American Foreign Policy- ranging from WWI to present day and the Ukraine war. I learned how to analyse these situations for motivations, strategies, and goals. I learned how to write succinctly and apply my analysis to foreign policy context

I learned an immense amount about not just US foreign policy in the 20th century but also gained an invaluable understanding of how diplomacy actually functions. You learn how to identify national interests, strategies, and tactics in an incredibly useful schema for analyzing policy decisions. You also learn how to make your points quickly and defend them well- because Ford will press you.
A broad overview of American Foreign Policy
A deeper understanding of how American foreign policy has evolved over presidential administrations and the external environment leading to those changes.
I learnt so much about the history of American Foreign policy and different schools of thought. I further pushed my reading, writing and speaking skills.

This class teaches you to read closely and to think beyond the readings. It allows you to explore your own interests in the field of American foreign policy, but also to focus specifically on some key moments. Ambassador Ford leads discussions exceptionally well and gives very helpful feedback on writing.
I learned about about key foreign policy decisions made in the past decade.
How to evaluate the strategy and tactics of US policymakers. A deeper understanding of key foreign policy events in US history, and the opportunity to talk through these events with Ambassador Ford.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Great professor with unique and relevant experience, interesting readings.
Weaknesses: The readings are on the long side, so sometimes they are hard to get through. Paper assignments are very open-ended, which can be both good and bad at times.

Class revolves around going through the readings on the whiteboard and analyzing them structurally. I wish it were a little more seminar-y, with less trying to remember facts from the readings. Aside from that I learned a lot and would take the class again.

Strengths are Ambassador Ford and the focus on reading books. Professor Ford brings a wealth of of experience and practice to the table and cares deeply about his students and their learning experience. No major weaknesses except for size of the class was perhaps too large.

Strength: Ford is great; the books are for the most part good and serve as a great way to learn about FP. I was a little shocked at how in detail Ford comment's on one's writing, but in the end his comments and suggestions make you a better writer.

Professor Ford is a wonderful teacher. Rarely do we have the opportunity in life to learn from such a knowledgeable figure and engage in material theyve spent their lives dedicated to in a seminar setting. The material was well paced  and engaging

Strengths: Ford himself is the real strength. He teaches the class incredibly well, and facilitates the most engaged discussions I have seen in my 3 years at this school. He makes sure you both understand the material and why you are learning it. The course also attracts students that really care - and they make you better in turn. 

Weaknesses: there is a ton of reading- which is excellent if you can do it. But it may come at the cost of your other classes. Be warned.
A lot of reading, some of it felt extraneous (certain books could be narrowed down to a few chapters)
Strength: The class is incredibly engaging, not a single moment where I felt bored or uninterested. Ambassador Ford is fantastic in this seminar, take the class if you get into it

Strengths: this is an incredible class, truly wonderful. The readings are engaging, class discussion is fascinating and Professor Ford puts so much care into his students. I also really like that the assignments help develop skills that will be valuable in the field including writing concisely and speaking.

Weaknesses: none!

The strengths of this course are the teaching and the small seminar style. The assignments are clearly laid out and fair. Each week I really enjoyed the student presentations and thought class flew by. I don't really have any weaknesses in all honesty.

Strengths: readings are really great, teacher is very engaged with the class material

Weaknesses: readings are too long, not enough conversation in the class

Ambassador Ford is a really great professor, who cares a lot about his students learning and is very available for office hours. I received detailed feedback on both my oral presentation and my first paper, which helped me better understand how to critique foreign policy. It's also a really cool opportunity to hear Ambassador Ford speak from his experience as a diplomat and cover how these kinds of policy decisions are actually made.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I really enjoyed this class. Prof. Ford is an engaging and supportive teacher, and the material is a great combination of diplomacy, history, and memoir. Highly recommend for anyone interested in learning how international relations actually works.
Instantly. Ambassador Ford is bright and loves talking about foreign policy, especially with his past experience.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn more about the history and inner workings of American foreign policy. Cant recommend Ambassador Ford enough  the Ambassador is reason enough to take this course.
Yes if you want to get a good understanding of America's successes and failures around the world.
Absolutely. Professor Ford is wonderful and it was incredible to learn from him. The seminar setting made the material that much more engaging

Absolutely take this class if you can. If you care at all about US foreign policy or diplomacy, it is the best possible education you can get at this school. Genuinely, the course changed how I think about policy and the US role in the world. 

Ford is also Excellent- he means it when he says come to office hours. Thats a ton of the value of the class, and I wish I had realized that earlier. 

That said, this course requires you to work. Not only can ford tell if you havent done the reading, you also just get way less out of a seminar session if you didnt prepare- youll feel worse off for having skipped the reading. 

In sum though - make this class your priority. Its just worth it.
Good course, you get what it says on the tin.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone with a remote interest in American foreign policythis class made me reconsider
my career after graduation. Thats
how strong of an impression this class made on me.
Absolutely! If you get a chance to take this course you must. Professor Ford is incredible and this is easily the best class I have taken at Yale
Yes definitely -- you should be prepared to do the reading but gain lots from doing so! Ambassador Ford is an amazing instructor who cares deeply about students. Recommend to all.

Yes, I really enjoyed this course and learned a lot from it. Not only is Ambassador Ford a great professor, he is also a great mentor to his students and often would share events and opportunities that we should look into. I have taken a number of policy courses in my time at Yale, but this one really emphasized key lessons from each week's readings, and the way Ambassador Ford taught the course kept us all accountable to doing the readings thoughtfully and extracting key takeaways from them.
